importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Fiscal year 2026 began on October 1, 2025, leading to a government shutdown and a funding lapse for the WIC program.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from October 1 to October 20, 2025, encompasses the government shutdown and the White House's announcement of using tariff revenue to fund WIC during this critical gap.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration announced it would redirect Section 32 tariff revenue—typically used for child nutrition—to fund WIC during the government shutdown.
WIC, serving nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children, was at risk of shutting down due to lack of federal funding.
The National WIC Association welcomed efforts to sustain the program but expressed concern over uncertainty in funding amount, delivery speed, and duration.
Legal experts question the administration’s authority, noting that Congress has not appropriated funds for WIC, and tariff revenue is frozen without legislative designation.
House Speaker Mike Johnson criticized Democrats for causing the shutdown and blaming them for halting WIC operations.
WIC has bipartisan support and is seen as a crucial safety net, especially amid rising inflation and food costs.
The program received $7.6 billion in FY2025 funding, with the Senate proposing $8.2 billion for FY2026, while the House plan would maintain funding at current levels but reduce benefits.
Tariff revenue collected so far this year totals $190 billion, with Section 232 tariffs imposed for national security reasons (e.g., aluminum, steel, cars).

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive office of the President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House announced a plan to use tariff revenue to fund WIC during the shutdown, showing executive action in response to a government funding crisis.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal food assistance program for pregnant women, new mothers, and young children
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is central to the article as the program at risk during the shutdown and the target of the tariff funding plan.

namedEntities.name: Section 32 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of tariff that supports child nutrition programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Section 32 tariff revenue is being redirected to fund WIC during the shutdown, illustrating a shift in tariff use policy.

namedEntities.name: Section 232 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariffs imposed on goods for national security reasons
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration initially proposed redirecting Section 232 revenue, which was later changed to Section 32 revenue, highlighting policy adjustments under scrutiny.

namedEntities.name: Karoline Leavitt
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly announced the tariff funding plan on social media, framing it as a response to Democratic inaction during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: House Speaker of the United States Congress
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He criticized Democrats for causing the shutdown and blamed them for the halt in WIC operations, emphasizing political polarization.

namedEntities.name: Chris Towner
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He questioned the legal basis of redirecting tariff funds, highlighting constitutional and procedural concerns about executive spending authority.

namedEntities.name: National WIC Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The advocacy group representing WIC program participants
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The group expressed concern over the short-term, uncertain nature of the funding solution and advocated for long-term stability in WIC funding.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the political figure behind the administration's decision to use tariff revenue to fund WIC, linking economic policy to social welfare during a crisis.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body responsible for federal spending decisions
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Congress has failed to pass a spending bill, leading to the shutdown and prompting the executive branch to act, highlighting a constitutional standoff.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency responsible for administering WIC
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA confirmed the funding lapse and provided contingency funds, showing agency-level coordination during the crisis.

namedEntities.name: Fiscal year 2026
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The annual budget period that began on October 1, 2025
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The start of FY2026 triggered the shutdown and funding gap that led to the WIC emergency funding proposal.

namedEntities.name: Axios
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Media outlet that first reported the White House's effort
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Axios was the first to report the administration's plan, indicating media visibility and public interest in the policy shift.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby and Samantha Waldenberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are the authors of the article, providing journalistic context and reporting on the political and policy dynamics.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: News network that published the article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CNN provided the primary source and context for public awareness of the tariff-WIC funding plan during the shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the 2025 U.S. government shutdown, the Trump administration announced it would use Section 32 tariff revenue—normally allocated to child nutrition programs—to fund the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC), which serves nearly 7 million vulnerable families. This decision follows a funding lapse as Congress failed to pass a fiscal year 2026 spending bill. While the National WIC Association welcomed the effort, it expressed deep concern over uncertainty regarding the amount, speed, and duration of funding. Legal experts, including Chris Towner, raised questions about the legality of redirecting tariff revenue without congressional appropriation. The move reflects broader political tensions, with House Speaker Mike Johnson blaming Democrats for the shutdown and framing WIC as a victim of partisan inaction. The article highlights both the urgency of sustaining essential social programs and the constitutional and procedural challenges of executive action during a legislative deadlock.
title: White House says it will use tariff revenue to fund federal food aid for mothers and young children
